results.title: Artwork design
results.brief_description: Shows how a rough sketch of a circuit proceeds through definite stages to master art work from which a circuit board can later be made.

results.title: Theatre: getting your act together
results.brief_description: Presents a behind-the-scenes look at the theatre and the roles of the playwright, director, actor and theatre production staff. Designed to promote students’ interest in the theatre and to provide them with an insight into the workings of two professional theatre companies - The Melbourne Theatre Company and Sydney’s King O’Malley Theatre Company. The program is divided into five sections: 1 What is theatre? 2 The playwright in society. 3 In rehearsal. 4 The performance. 5 Theatre in society.

results.title: The Youth who wanted to shiver
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Acton Films and Bosustow Entertainment

video_links.name: The Youth who wanted to shiver

results.brief_description: An animated adaptation of the classic fairy tale by the Brothers Grimm, about Jack who knows no fear and wants to be able to shiver. All help fails until his bride pours a bucket of tiny fish over him.

results.title: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm's fairy tale
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow, Churchill Films and Bosustow Entertainment

video_links.name: Fisherman & his wife: a Grimm's fairy tale

results.brief_description: A Grimm’s fairy tale about a humble fisherman who frees a prince from a spell. The fisherman’s wife siezes the opportunity to have all her wishes granted but ends up where she started, thus learning a bitter lesson.

results.title: Red Nightmare
results.creator_credit: George Waggner, William L. Hendricks, United States. Dept. of Defense and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An anti communist drama sponsored by the U.S Government, supervised by Jack L. Warner and produced during the Cold War. The drama revolves around a small town American who takes his civil liberties for granted until he dreams of a communist takeover which jolts him out of his complacency. Narrated by Jack Webb. Photographed by Robert Hoffman. Written by Vincent Fotre. Music by William Lava. Edited by Folmer Blargsted. Starring Jack Kelly, Jeanne Cooper, Andrew Duggan, Peter Brown, Patricia Woodell, Peter Breck, Robert Conrad, Mike Road.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Waggner, William L. Hendricks, United States. Dept. of Defense and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: A colourful clay animation film which satirizes society and its impulse to invent nuclear weapons which cause self-destruction. Looks at the invention of destructive weapons from raspberries to rockets! Narration: Brian Woods. Animation: Mark D’Arcy-Irvine, Masfufah Sani. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Billabong
results.brief_description: Set among the red gums, this film captures the mood of one day on the Murray River, Echuca, Victoria. Shows where thousands of birds come to breed each year.

results.title: Suburban streetscape: living Hawthorn 1906 & 1979
results.creator_credit: Deakin University, Michael Rogers and Weston Bate
results.brief_description: Compares 1906 footage of the main streets of the Melbourne suburb of Hawthorn with footage of the same streets in 1979. Contains b&w footage.

results.title: ASL interpreter at Rihanna's Super Bowl performance shines
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @EyezQueenRF's Tiktok post
results.brief_description: Justina Miles is the first female deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew much love online. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”
results.title_for_label: ASL interpreter at Rihanna’s Super Bowl performance shines
results.description: Justina Miles is the first woman deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew love from all over the internet. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”
description_for_label: Justina Miles is the first woman deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew love from all over the internet. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”

results.title: Jenny Watson, painter
results.brief_description:
“Jenny Watson, painter” is an interview Sue Ford conducted with fellow Australian artist Jenny Watson in 1975 at the latter’s studio and home on Punt Road, Richmond. The two artists discuss feminism, art and the relationship between art and life in this insightful interview and document of the time.

Jenny Watson (born 25 October 1951) is a leading Australian artist known for her practice intertwining painting with autobiographical and fictional narratives that interrogate the construction of femininity and self. Drawing from personal histories, punk and feminism, her painting practice has developed a unique style since the 1970s, incorporating fabric, text and collage. She has exhibited extensively in Australia and internationally, and her work is held in the collections of the Museum of Contemporary Art, the National Gallery of Australia and the National Gallery of Victoria.

In this 1975 interview, Watson reflects on the current state of art and the changes brought about by the introduction of video, performance, documentation and body art, highlighting the emergence of the personal or subjective within art practice. She discusses the difficulties facing women working in art such as a domestic situation, motherhood, or not being taken seriously; conversely, she points out the support provided by a community of women.

Watson goes on to discuss the shift towards the personal, figurative and diaristic in her recent work, particularly reflecting on the “Horse” series she created in the early 1970s. Filmed standing in front of her most recent body of work, a series of life-size portraits including one of her then-partner, artist John Nixon (“Yellow Painting: John”, 1974), and one of herself, Watson introduces the formal framework and her exploration of the subjective figure.

The interview is a fascinating insight into the development of an important Australian artist’s practice, as well as a testament to the interwoven personal relationships between artists of the period.
